member.summary: DFT Class

member.name: P:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.IsUsingCached
member.summary: Read only Boolean property. True meas the currently defined DFT is using cached memory to speed up calculations.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.Initialize(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Pre-Initializes the DFT. Must call first and this anytime the FFT setup changes.
member.param: True will force the DFT to not use pre-calculated caching.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.Execute(System.Double[])
member.summary: Execute the DFT.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.Dft(System.Double[])
member.summary: A brute force DFT - Uses Task / Parallel pattern

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.DftCached(System.Double[])
member.summary: DFT with Pre-calculated Sin/Cos arrays + Task / Parallel pattern. DFT can only be so big before the computer runs out of memory and has to use the brute force DFT.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.ThirdParty.DSPLib.DFT.FrequencySpan(System.Double)
member.summary: Return the Frequency Array for the currently defined DFT. Takes into account the total number of points and zero padding points that were defined.

members.member:
Performs an in-place complex FFT.
Released under the MIT License
Core FFT class based on, Fast C# FFT - Copyright (c) 2010 Gerald T. Beauregard
Changes to: Interface, scaling, zero padding, return values. Change to .NET Complex output types and integrated with my DSP Library. Note: Complex Number Type requires .NET >= 4.0
These changes as noted above Copyright (c) 2016 Steven C. Hageman
Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:

members.member:
Many of the windows functions are based on the article,
Spectrum and spectral density estimation by the Discrete Fourier transform (DFT), including a comprehensive list of window functions and some new ï¬‚at-top windows.
G. Heinzel, A. Rudiger and R. Schilling, Max-Planck-Institut fur Gravitationsphysik
February 15, 2002

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.FeatureExtraction.PSI(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Double},System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the physical stillness index, specified in the paper referenced below. Chang, Kang-Ming, et al. "A wireless accelerometer-based body posture stability detection system and its application for meditation practitioners." Sensors 12.12 (2012): 17620-17632. Calculates a metric of physical stillness from acceleration readings. Uses a sliding window, root mean square filter to get the absolute magnitude of the overall acceleration in the readings. This method works with the absolute magnitude of accelerations and not three-axis readings, use PSIVector for those purposes.
member.param: List of acceleration readings
Output PSI, the average of the filtered output
Output PSI, the max value of the filtered output
The number of values to incorporate in the window on both sides
member.returns: The output filtered list of RMS values, can be discarded in favor of 'out' variables

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.FeatureExtraction.PSIVector(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Double}},System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs the calculation of the physical stillness index using a 3D acceleration vector
member.param: List of acceleration readings
Output PSI, the average of the filtered output
Output PSI, the max value of the filtered output
The number of values to incorporate in the window on both sides
member.returns: The output filtered list of RMS values, can be discarded in favor of 'out' variables

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.FeatureExtraction.RootMeanSquare(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the root mean square of the input variables
member.param: Calculated first term of form - 1/2n
The square sum of the input values

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.FeatureExtraction.SquareSummation(System.Double)
member.summary: Performs square of input values

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.FeatureExtraction.SquareSummation(System.Numerics.Vector3)
member.summary: Performs square summation of Vector3 variables
member.param: Vector3 with x, y, and z values

member.summary: Removes mean from each axis of the 3D vector
member.param: 3D acceleration vector
Mean of X axis
Mean of Y axis
Mean of Z axis

members.member:
Uses the approximate first derivative of the GSR signal to find the magnitude, duration, and amplitude of the peaks in the signal.
Healey, Jennifer Anne. Wearable and automotive systems for affect recognition from physiology. Diss. Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2000.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.SumFeatures(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Double[]})
member.param: Output of the GetPeakFeatures function

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.FindAbove(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns indices above a threshold, removes zero elements. Intended for time-series data collection.
member.param: An array of data.
The threshold for inclusion in return data.
The sampling rate of the data.
member.returns: List of List of indices above the threshold.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.FindZeroCrossings(System.Double[])
member.summary: Find zero crossings for two cases: 1. Goes from below zero to above zero 2. Goes from above zero to below zero
member.param: Array to find the indices of zero crossings in
member.returns: A tuple of the form: Item1 is case one and Item2 is case twos

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.ConstructPeaks(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32}},System.Tuple{System.Int32[],System.Int32[]})
member.summary: Takes the zero crossings and peaks and reconstructs the index range for the peaks.
member.param: List of List of indices that represent the indices above threshold
List of indices where zero crossings happen

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.FindNearestMinus(System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Finds the nearest index for zero crossings that go from above zero to below zero
member.param: Peak starting index
Array of indices that represent the zero crossing points
member.returns: int, the index in ZeroCrossings that is closest to PeakStart

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.FindNearestPlus(System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Finds the nearest index for zero crossings that go from below zero to above zero
member.param: Peak starting index
Array of indices that represent the zero crossing points
member.returns: int, the index in ZeroCrossings that is closest to PeakStart

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.MergeOverlappingPeaks(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32[]})
member.summary: If reconstructed peaks are overlapping in their indices, which can happen if a peak does not zero cross before the next peak, then remove the copies.
member.param: List of indices for the reconstructed peaks
member.returns: List with any overlapping peaks removed

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.HealeyStressDetection.FiniteDifference(System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Calculates the differences between adjacent elements, equating to the approximate first derivative Algorithm: Y = [X(1)-X(0), X(2)-X(1), ..., X(m + 1)-X(m)] Source: https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/diff.html?s_tid=srchtitle

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.TarvainenDetrending.RemoveTrend(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: A time-varying finite-impulse-response high-pass filter for detrending If using this in a published study, cite: Tarvainen, Mika P., Perttu O. Ranta-Aho, and Pasi A.Karjalainen. "An advanced detrending method with application to HRV analysis." IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering 49.2 (2002): 172-175.
member.param: Original EDA signal
The 'smoothing' factor of the filter
Coefficients for the 0, 1, 2 diagonals in the second derivative matrix. Can be null, will default to standard value
member.returns: Filtered signal without a trend, double[]

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.DataProcessing.TarvainenDetrending.GetResidual(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Removes the stationary signal from the EDA signal and returns the residual signal
member.param: Original EDA signal
Output of RemoveTrend function

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.MachineLearningUtilities.DataImport.LoadCollectedDataset(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses and transforms the data collected from a biosensor from a txt file. To facilitate training the Fast Forest classifier used, the WESAD data is loaded in first to allow retraining.
member.param: The top directory of the WESAD dataset.
The top directory with the data.
The search pattern to find the relevant files in the DirectoryPath.
The window size, in seconds, for collecting data. Defaults to 5 seconds.
member.returns: List of Tuples with data and tags.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.MachineLearningUtilities.DataImport.LoadDataset(System.String)
member.summary: Loads in a CSV datasets from the filesystem from the WESAD dataset.
member.param: The top directory with the data.
member.returns: List of Tuples with Subject ID, sensor data, and tags.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.MachineLearningUtilities.DataImport.SchmidtDatasetPipeline(System.String,Microsoft.ML.MLContext,Microsoft.ML.DataOperationsCatalog.TrainTestData@,Microsoft.ML.DataOperationsCatalog.TrainTestData@,Microsoft.ML.DataOperationsCatalog.TrainTestData@,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Pipeline implemented to process the WESAD dataset. Schmidt, Philip, et al. "Introducing wesad, a multimodal dataset for wearable stress and affect detection." Proceedings of the 20th ACM International Conference on Multimodal Interaction. 2018.
member.param: The top directory with the data.
The Microsoft.ML context.
The returned TrainTestData for the multi-class models.
The returned TrainTestData for the binary models.
The returned TrainTestData for the regression models.
The window size, in seconds, for collecting data. Defaults to 5 seconds.
The percentage of the data that is train and test. Default is 0.1.

member.param: The Microsoft.ML context.
The data and tags loaded in.
The percentage of the data that is train and test. Default is 0.1.
member.returns: The TrainTestData to be used in training a Microsoft.ML model.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.InputPipeline.SignalProcessing.ProcessAccSignal(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Method to compute features for 3-axis accelerometer signals.
member.param: An array of accelerometer data, packaged in [X, Y, Z] format in a single array.
The sampling rate of the sensor. Defaults to 32 Hz.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.InputPipeline.SignalProcessing.ProcessTmpSignal(System.Double[])
member.summary: Method to compute the features of the temperature signal.
member.param: An array containing the temperature sensor readings.

member.name: M:MMIVR.BiosensorFramework.InputPipeline.SignalProcessing.ProcessPpgSignal(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method to compute the features for the PPG signal.
member.param: An array containing readings from the PPG sensor.
The sampling rate of the sensor. Defaults to 64 Hz.
The signal threshold for feature computation. Defaults to 3.5.
The peak size needed for feature computation. Defaults to 3.
